page.title: 11Local History
page.content: {Chesterfield Canal: The Chesterfield Canal was surveyed by the famous James Brindley in 1769 but he had died before it was completed in 1777.It was originally 46 miles long and joined Chesterfield to West Stockwith (with outlet therefore to the River Trent and the Sea) and provided an outlet for such goods as coal,iron,stone,corn,lime,timber, pottery and ale. It declined with the advent of railways, hastened by a tunnel collapse in the one and a half mile long Norwood tunnel in 1908 but trade managed to hang on until 1955.Still visible on some bridge uprights are marks scored by the ropes of horse drawn barges. Today it is navigable for 26miles and is most attractive for much of its length:uses_ fishing,cruising,walking.
